title: pint-convert does not work anymore after freezing UnitDefinition
body: Since last releases, UnitDefinition has been frozen but pint-convert script was mutating it to inject correlation uncertainties between constant.

title: Locale-based formatting TypeError
body:
For localization of units I am testing pint + babel as per [tutorial example](https://pint.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tutorial.html#localizing). I suspect the babel-provided CLDR data is not properly parsed or passed to the pint formatter based off the stack-trace.

Example:
```
ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
accel = 1.3 * ureg['meter/second**2']
print(str(accel.format_babel(locale='fr_FR')))

ureg = pint.UnitRegistry(fmt_locale='fr_FR')
accel = 1.3 * ureg['meter/second**2']
print(str(accel))
```
Expected output:
```
>> '1.3 mètre par seconde²'
>> '1.3 mètre par seconde²'
```
Stacktrace / error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/gilles/repos/testpint/test.py", line 5, in <module>
    str(accel.format_babel(locale='fr_FR'))
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/quantity.py", line 483, in format_babel
    obj.units.format_babel(spec, **kwspec),
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/unit.py", line 124, in format_babel
    return units.format_babel(spec, registry=self._REGISTRY, **kwspec)
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/util.py", line 466, in format_babel
    return format_unit(self, spec, registry=registry, **kwspec)
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/formatting.py", line 411, in format_unit
    return fmt(unit, registry=registry, **options)
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/formatting.py", line 227, in format_default
    return formatter(
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/formatting.py", line 366, in formatter
    neg_ret = _join(division_fmt, neg_terms)
  File "/Users/gilles/.local/share/virtualenvs/testpint-hlpj48ZU/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/formatting.py", line 42, in _join
    if not __JOIN_REG_EXP.search(fmt):
TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object
```

Python version: 3.9
pint==0.19.2
babel==2.10.1

title: Decimal registry parses unit expression without scaling factor using float instead of decimal
body:
I found the following unexpected difference between float type and decimal type registries:

```
import decimal
import pint

ur = pint.UnitRegistry(non_int_type=decimal.Decimal)

pint.Quantity("m/s").to("km/h")  # <Quantity(3.6, 'kilometer / hour')>
ur.Quantity("m/s").to("km/h")  # fails with TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'float' and 'decimal.Decimal'
```
If I add an explicit scaling factor, it works as expected:
```
pint.Quantity("1m/s").to("km/h")  # <Quantity(3.6, 'kilometer / hour')>
ur.Quantity("1m/s").to("km/h")  # <Quantity(3.60000, 'kilometer / hour')>
```

I think that underlying this there's a problem with the parsing of the input string, but I could use some help figuring out where the float is being introduced.

Here's what a relevant test could look like:
```
def test_decimal_magnitude():
    ur = pint.UnitRegistry(non_int_type=decimal.Decimal)

    assert isinstance(ur.Quantity("1m/s").magnitude, decimal.Decimal)
    assert not isinstance(ur.Quantity("m/s").magnitude, float)  # unexpected success (magnitude should not be a float)
    assert isinstance(ur.Quantity("m/s").magnitude, decimal.Decimal)  # unexpected fail (magnitude should be a decimal)
```

Both `pint==0.18` and `pint==0.19.1` have this problem.

title: to_reduced_units() fails with g*t/kg
body:
In am trying to run the following example:
```
import pint

ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
 
ridiculous_factor = 0.5 * ureg.g * ureg.t / ureg.kg
ridiculous_factor.to_reduced_units()
```
But this fails with:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
DimensionalityError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-211-e3a1dda5eff7> in <module>
      4 
      5 ridiculous_factor = 0.5 * ureg.g * ureg.t / ureg.kg
----> 6 ridiculous_factor.to_reduced_units()

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in to_reduced_units(self)
    800         # can we make this more efficient?
    801         newq = copy.copy(self)
--> 802         newq.ito_reduced_units()
    803         return newq
    804 

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in ito_reduced_units(self)
    790                         break
    791 
--> 792         return self.ito(newunits)
    793 
    794     def to_reduced_units(self) -> Quantity[_MagnitudeType]:

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in ito(self, other, *contexts, **ctx_kwargs)
    699         other = to_units_container(other, self._REGISTRY)
    700 
--> 701         self._magnitude = self._convert_magnitude(other, *contexts, **ctx_kwargs)
    702         self._units = other
    703 

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in _convert_magnitude(self, other, *contexts, **ctx_kwargs)
    678                 return self._REGISTRY.convert(self._magnitude, self._units, other)
    679 
--> 680         return self._REGISTRY.convert(
    681             self._magnitude,
    682             self._units,

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/registry.py in convert(self, value, src, dst, inplace)
   1001             return value
   1002 
-> 1003         return self._convert(value, src, dst, inplace)
   1004 
   1005     def _convert(self, value, src, dst, inplace=False, check_dimensionality=True):

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/registry.py in _convert(self, value, src, dst, inplace)
   1915                 value, src = src._magnitude, src._units
   1916 
-> 1917         return super()._convert(value, src, dst, inplace)
   1918 
   1919     def _get_compatible_units(self, input_units, group_or_system):

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/registry.py in _convert(self, value, src, dst, inplace)

   1517         if not (src_offset_unit or dst_offset_unit):
-> 1518             return super()._convert(value, src, dst, inplace)

~/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pint/registry.py in _convert(self, value, src, dst, inplace, check_dimensionality)
   1034             # then the conversion cannot be performed.
   1035             if src_dim != dst_dim:
-> 1036                 raise DimensionalityError(src, dst, src_dim, dst_dim)
   1037 
   1038         # Here src and dst have only multiplicative units left. Thus we can

DimensionalityError: Cannot convert from 'gram * metric_ton / kilogram' ([mass]) to 'dimensionless' (dimensionless)
```
If I replace the `g` with `kg` all works as expected.  
Version is v0.18

Any pointer appreciated.

title: Wrong calculation when using temperature prefixes
body:
I'm doing following conversion:

```
from pint import UnitRegistry

ureg = UnitRegistry()
t = ureg.Quantity(20, ureg.degC)
print(t.to(ureg.millidegC))
```

output:
`293150.0 millidegree_Celsius`

It seems like prefixes for degree Celsius are not handled correctly. The result should be 20000 millidegree_Celsius.
Looks like it changes the unit to Kelvin internally.
It this a known issue? Is there a workaround for my use case?

title: "Redefining" warning raised when @alias being added
body:
When trying to add `@alias` definitions for particular units (see `degree_Celsius` example below), the registry warns of redefinition when it is just adding a new alias. This doesn't happen for all units, but not sure why (see `volt` example below).


## `degree_Celsius` example
```pycon
In [1]: import logging; logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

In [2]: from pint import UnitRegistry; ureg = UnitRegistry()

In [3]: ureg.parse_expression('degC')
Out[3]: 1 <Unit('degree_Celsius')>

In [4]: ureg.define('@alias degree_Celsius = Deg_C')
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining 'degree_Celsius' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining '°C' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining 'celsius' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining 'degC' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining 'degreeC' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)
WARNING:pint.util:Redefining 'Deg_C' (<class 'pint.definitions.UnitDefinition'>)

In [5]: ureg.parse_expression('Deg_C')
Out[5]: 1 <Unit('degree_Celsius')>
```

## `volt` example
```pycon
In [1]: import logging; logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

In [2]: from pint import UnitRegistry; ureg = UnitRegistry()

...

In [20]: ureg.parse_expression('volt')
Out[20]: 1 <Unit('volt')>

In [21]: ureg.define('@alias volt = Volt = vlt = Vlt = v')

In [22]: ureg.parse_expression('Vlt')
Out[22]: 1 <Unit('volt')>
```

title: how to avoid float/int casting error with to_reduced_units() on integer arrays
body:
What is the best approach to avoid casting errors when working with integer arrays? Is there any way to enforce casting to `float` for unit conversions?

The following example works with `to_base_units()` on all inputs but fails with `to_reduced_units()` once any kind of array gets introduced:
~~~python
import pint
ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
Q_ = ureg.Quantity

Q_(3, "s * ms").to_base_units() # works
Q_([3,4], "s * ms").to_base_units() # works, results are float

Q_(3, "s * ms").to_reduced_units() # works
Q_([3,4], "s * ms").to_reduced_units() # fails

UFuncTypeError: Cannot cast ufunc 'multiply' output from dtype('float64') to dtype('int32') with casting rule 'same_kind'
~~~
`to_reduced_units()` seems call `ito_reduced_units()` almost immediately which produces the error.

With `force_ndarray_like=True` it obviously stops working for scalar inputs as well.
~~~python
import pint
ureg = pint.UnitRegistry(force_ndarray_like=True)
Q_ = ureg.Quantity

Q_(3, "s * ms").to_reduced_units()

UFuncTypeError: Cannot cast ufunc 'multiply' output from dtype('float64') to dtype('int32') with casting rule 'same_kind'
~~~

If possible I would like to catch this behavior as early as possible because it can be quite confusing for new users who might not consider explicitly casting their inputs as `float` and encounter this error at some later point during their analysis.

title: Original object modified when subtracting degree_Farenheit from delta_degree_Celsius
body:
Example code to repeat the issue:
`from pint import Quantity`
`test1 = Quantity([-287.78,  -32.24,   -1.94,   -1.94], 'delta_degree_Celsius')`
`test2 = Quantity(70.0, 'degree_Fahrenheit')`
`test1-test2`

This results in the value of test1 being unintentionally modified to `Quantity([-518.004,  -58.032,   -3.492,   -3.492], 'delta_degree_Celsius')`. The incorrect line in the source is linked here:
https://github.com/hgrecco/pint/blob/3d99581a808f8c0b5445bb43820a2b82815425d1/pint/quantity.py#L1030
The linked line should be corrected to read:
`magnitude = op(self.to(tu).magnitude, other._magnitude)`

(First bug report so let me know if something should be adjusted)

title: Quantity __new__ not parsing units string properly if some metric terms are abbreviated and some are not
body:
When I run the code
```
from pint import UnitRegistry
ureg = UnitRegistry()
unit_str = "cm centimeter cm centimeter"
print(ureg.Quantity(1.0, units=ureg(unit_str)))
print(ureg.Quantity(1.0, units=unit_str))
```
I get the output
```
1.0 centimeter ** 4
1.0 centimeter ** 2
```

I expect the output
```
1.0 centimeter ** 4
1.0 centimeter ** 4
```

It seems like if `units` is a string, then `cm` in `units` is getting ignored if `centimeter` is present.

This is with `pint 0.14`.

title: Pickled Quantity Changes Type
body:
Pickling and un-pickling a quantity will cause type coercion between the dynamic `Quantity` class defined by a `UnitRegistry` and the global `Quantity` class. 

This leads to exceptions being raised when comparing quantities which have been pickled with those that haven't:

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

```
import pint
import pickle

ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
pint.set_application_registry(ureg)

x = 1.0 * ureg.kelvin
y = pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(x))

z = x > y
```
(tested with `pint ==0.10.1`)

## Exception Raised

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "xxx/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 3331, in run_code
    exec(code_obj, self.user_global_ns, self.user_ns)
  File "<ipython-input-2-1f849a21d3d1>", line 10, in <module>
    z = x > y
  File "xxx/python3.7/site-packages/pint/quantity.py", line 1484, in <lambda>
    __gt__ = lambda self, other: self.compare(other, op=operator.gt)
  File "xxx/python3.7/site-packages/pint/quantity.py", line 106, in wrapped
    result = f(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "xxx/python3.7/site-packages/pint/quantity.py", line 1471, in compare
    raise ValueError("Cannot compare Quantity and {}".format(type(other)))
ValueError: Cannot compare Quantity and <class 'pint.quantity.Quantity'>
```

title: non-quantity constant_values parameter to pad
body:
Passing non-quantity parameters to `np.pad` in `constant` mode results in behaviour different from passing `dimensionless` quantities:
```python
In [1]: import numpy as np 
   ...: import pint 
   ...: ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()

In [2]: a = np.arange(5) * ureg.m

In [3]: np.pad(a, (2, 4), mode="constant", constant_values=4)                                                                                                                                                                   
Out[3]: array([4, 4, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4]) <Unit('meter')>

In [4]: np.pad(a, (2, 4), mode="constant", constant_values=4 * ureg.dimensionless)                                                                                                                                              
DimensionalityError: Cannot convert from 'dimensionless' (dimensionless) to 'meter' ([length])
```
I'd expect `[3]` and `[4]` to be equivalent, but one of the checks in `test_pad` seems to expect the current behaviour so I'm not sure if this is a misconception on my part.

title: TypeError: __array__() takes 1 positional argument but 2 were given
body:
Looks like a bug crept into 0.10 when `PINT_ARRAY_PROTOCOL_FALLBACK` is `'0'`:
```python
import os
os.environ['PINT_ARRAY_PROTOCOL_FALLBACK'] = '0'

import numpy as np
import pint

q = pint.Quantity(np.arange(3, dtype=np.float32), 'm')
np.array(q) # OK
np.array(q, dtype=np.float64) # Error
```
The last one yields:
```pytb
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-ba6cd2ac8160> in <module>
      8 np.array(q)
      9 
---> 10 np.array(q, dtype=np.float64)

TypeError: __array__() takes 1 positional argument but 2 were given
```

I think that's because the `__array__` implementation does not accept any args:
https://github.com/hgrecco/pint/blob/a70be489c46c03ca15c2832a308a56a556270461/pint/quantity.py#L1554-L1560

PR with tests incoming...

(attn: @jthielen)

title: IndexError on assigning units to empty Numpy array (Pint 0.10)
body:
Since the 0.10 update if I try to assign units to an empty array, I get an IndexError

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import pint
>>> ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
>>> x = np.array([])
>>> x*ureg('kg')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Users\mll13652\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs\py37\lib\site-packages\pint\quantity.py", line 1507, in __array_ufunc__
    return numpy_wrap("ufunc", ufunc, inputs, kwargs, types)
  File "C:\Users\mll13652\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs\py37\lib\site-packages\pint\numpy_func.py", line 888, in numpy_wrap
    return handled[name](*args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\mll13652\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs\py37\lib\site-packages\pint\numpy_func.py", line 268, in implementation
    first_input_units = _get_first_input_units(args, kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\mll13652\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs\py37\lib\site-packages\pint\numpy_func.py", line 69, in _get_first_input_units
    return arg[0].units
IndexError: index 0 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 0
```

After looking into it a bit more it seems that in `_get_first_input_units`, `_is_quantity_sequence()` incorrectly returns `True` for empty arrays as the final check:
```
all(_is_quantity(item) for item in obj)
```
returns `True` for empty arrays.

One possible fix would be to get `sized` to also check for zero length and return `False`, preventing the check from getting to the above line, and I'd be happy enough to make a PR for this

title: `to_compact` handles prefixed units incorrectly.
body:
There is a bug in `to_compact` handling the `unit` argument

```python
>>> (1 * ureg.nanometer).to_compact(ureg.micrometer)
<Quantity(1.0000000000000002, 'millimicrometer')>
```

when the unit is prefixed

title: ureg.check fails to check dimensionless quantity
body:
Hello,

Thank you for this useful package.

I think there is an issue with the quantity type checking decorator. It doesn't raise any exception when the passed quantity is not dimensionless as expected.

Consider the following example:
```
import pint
ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
@ureg.check(ureg(''))
def f(x):
    return 2*x
print(f(ureg.Quantity(1, '')))
print(f(ureg.Quantity(1, 'm')))
```
The first call to "f" is correct, the second one should raise an exception but it doesn't happen.

Thanks to take some time to analyze this issue.

title: Mutated type in Quantity
body:
If I do a `np.shape` over a Quantity, the operation mutates the type of the `.magnitude`

See the example below :

``` 
#pint.__version__  ('0.8')
#numpy.__version__ ('1.10.1')

import pint
import numpy as np

ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()
q = ureg.Quantity(1)
print type(q.magnitude) # <type 'int'>
np.shape(q) #Out[6]: ()
print type(q.magnitude) # <type 'numpy.ndarray'>
```

title: Dimensionless base with dimensionless exponent: Cannot convert from 'dimensionless' to 'dimensionless'
body:
Raising the power to a dimensionless array gives a rather confusing error message:

```
In [3]: q = ureg.Quantity(array([1, 2, 3]), "dimensionless")

In [4]: q**q
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
DimensionalityError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-03e332c95cf3> in <module>()
----> 1 q**q

/dev/shm/gerrit/venv/stable-3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in __pow__(self, other)
    889                 #  len(array) quantities of len(set(array)) different units
    890                 if np.size(other) > 1:
--> 891                     raise DimensionalityError(self._units, 'dimensionless')
    892 
    893             new_self = self

DimensionalityError: Cannot convert from 'dimensionless' to 'dimensionless'

In [9]: 2**q
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
DimensionalityError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-9-91a1970227e2> in <module>()
----> 1 2**q

/dev/shm/gerrit/venv/stable-3.5/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pint/quantity.py in __rpow__(self, other)
    923             if isinstance(self._magnitude, ndarray):
    924                 if np.size(self._magnitude) > 1:
--> 925                     raise DimensionalityError(self._units, 'dimensionless')
    926             new_self = self.to_root_units()
    927             return other**new_self._magnitude

DimensionalityError: Cannot convert from 'dimensionless' to 'dimensionless'

```

I can see why I can't take the exponent of a dimensioned quantity, but it could give a more helpful error message.  And if both base and exponent are dimensionless there should not be any objection to carry out the operation.

title: ureg.wraps not returning correct units
body:
Before, I was able to abbreviate return units, e.g.
 ```python
@ureg.wraps(('kg'), 'meter')
def f(x):
    return x

x = Q_(1., 'meter')
y = f(x)
z = x*y
print z.units
```

Before, the 'kg' was automatically converted to 'kilograms' by `pint`. Now, after updating today from the master branch, if I try the above code I get a `KeyError: u'kg'`

I started using pint as it supports Decimal types, but seems like it's not handled in conversion with offset.

Here is an example:
```python
>>> from pint import UnitRegistry
>>> from decimal import Decimal
>>> UR = UnitRegistry()

<Quantity(0, 'kelvin')>
>>> q.to('celsius')
```

title: Comparison is valid in places that arithmetic is not
body:
Compare:

```
>>> u1 = pint.UnitRegistry()
>>> u2 = pint.UnitRegistry()
>>> 1*u1.m == 1*u2.m
True
>>> (1*u1.m - 1*u2.m).m == 0
ValueError: Cannot operate with Quantity and Quantity of different registries.
```

It seems weird to allow comparison but not arithmetic

title: arg() is malformed string with multiple-parameter context
body:
Hello,
I'm trying to define a multiple-parameter context to handle concentration calculations for solution chemistry. It seems that including multiple parameters in my context definition file triggers an error:

'While opening pint_custom_units.txt complex() arg is a malformed string'

The line that triggers the error is:
'@context(mw=0,volume=0,solvent_mass=0) chemistry = chem'

If I define only one parameter, the error is gone:
'@context(mw=0) chemistry = chem'

Unless I'm misinterpeting the documentation, this smells like a bug. Any help would be appreciated.

title: Dimensionless quantities behave unexpectedly when cast to int
body:
This is a variant of the old bug #54. It seems that the issue was fixed for floats, but casting to an int still causes issues. For example:

```
>>> q = Q_('1 kHz')/Q_('100 Hz')
>>> float(q)  # Behaves as expected
10.0
>>> int(q)  # Behaves unexpectedly
0
```

Presumably, adding an `__int__` method will fix this, though I haven't yet tried it.

title: UnitsContainer print
body:
Hi I want to print only the units of a quantity (for a label in a plot). But it doesn't print the abbreviated units  even if I am formatting it with ~
here is the code:

> > > from **init** import um,Q_
> > > x=125.3*um['l/s']
> > > print x
> > > 125.3 l/s
> > > x.units
> > > <UnitsContainer({'liter': 1.0, 'second': -1.0})>
> > > print x.units
> > > liter / second
> > > print '{:~}'.format(x.units)
> > > liter / second
> > > print '{:~L}'.format(x.units)
> > > \frac{liter}{second}

But with latex formatting works
is there a workaround?

Thanks for help

title: 'R' definied as both constant and unit
body:
First off thank you hgrecco for this fantastic package. I was about to set out writing something similar, when I realized that this does exactly what I was looking for!

I may have found an issue though. I'm trying to access the value of the molar gas constant stored in pint. (Forgive me if this isn't the correct method, I couldn't find anything in the documentation about accessing constants). And I realized that the name 'R' is used to refer both to the molar_gas_constant in constants_en.txt AND to the unit 'roentgen' in default_en.txt.

```
>>> unit=UnitRegistry()
>>> unit.R
<Quantity(1, 'roentgen')>
>>> unit.k
<Quantity(1, 'boltzmann_constant')>
```

I believe there should be separate names for each.

title: problem with constants (boltzmann_constant)
body:
Hello,
I recently started using this library and I really like it. I am new to python, but nevertheless I hope my comments will help a little.
Today I found a problem when working with predefined constants.
Here my example (calculating the velocity of a particle):

``` python
import numpy as np
from pint import UnitRegistry
ureg=UnitRegistry()

T=473*ureg.degK
m=132.9054519*ureg.amu
va=np.sqrt(2*ureg.k*T/m)

print(va)
2.6679283991697362 boltzmann_constant ** 0.5 * degK ** 0.5 / atomic_mass_unit ** 0.5
```

Of course I want to convert it to a convenient unit, but this results in an error that I don't really understand:

``` python
va.to_base_units()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-ea6209013126> in <module>()
----> 1 va.to_base_units()

    251 
    252         ret = copy.copy(self)
--> 253         ret.ito_base_units()
    254         return ret
    255 

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/quantity.py in ito_base_units(self)
    242         _, other = self._REGISTRY.get_base_units(self.units)
    243 
--> 244         self._magnitude = self._convert_magnitude(other)
    245         self._units = other
    246         return self

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/quantity.py in _convert_magnitude(self, other, *contexts, **ctx_kwargs)

    206 
--> 207         return self._REGISTRY.convert(self._magnitude, self._units, other)
    208

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/unit.py in convert(self, value, src, dst)
    877             return Decimal(str(factor)) * value
    878 
--> 879         return factor * value
    880 
    881     def pi_theorem(self, quantities):

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'NoneType' and 'float'
```

The same for

``` python
va.to(ureg.m/ureg.s)
```

My workaround was defining the Boltzmann constant by myself

``` python
boltmk=1.3806488e-23*ureg.J/ureg.K
vb=np.sqrt(2*boltmk*T/m)
vb.to_base_units()
243.2715198052687 meter/second
```

As far as I understand, the constants are just units themselves.
But defining my own Boltzmann constant unit raised also an error:

``` python
ureg.define('boltzmk = 1.3806488e-23 joule / degK')
ureg.boltzmk.to_base_units()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-26-c1e1448209d2> in <module>()
----> 1 ureg.boltzmk.to_base_units()

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/quantity.py in to_base_units(self)
    251 
    252         ret = copy.copy(self)
--> 253         ret.ito_base_units()
    254         return ret
    255 

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/quantity.py in ito_base_units(self)
    240         """
    241 
--> 242         _, other = self._REGISTRY.get_base_units(self.units)
    243 
    244         self._magnitude = self._convert_magnitude(other)

/usr/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Pint-0.4-py3.3.egg/pint/unit.py in get_base_units(self, input_units)
    812                 fac, uni = self.get_base_units(reg.reference)
    813                 if factor is not None:
--> 814                     factor *= (reg.converter.scale * fac) ** value
    815                 units *= uni ** value
    816 

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'float' and 'NoneType'
```

While reading the files for unit definiton (default_en.txt) and (constants_en.txt) I also saw that the symbol h is used for hour and for Planck constant.
I don't know if this was intended.

I am using pint 0.4 with python 3.3.3-1.

Thank You,
exxus

title: Name conflict between hour and Planck's constant
body:
constants_en.txt defines "h" as Planck's constant, but default_en.txt defines "h" as hour. The result is that ureg.h ends up as the hour.

I would recommend removing "h" from default_en.txt, since "hr" and "hour" are pretty good names for the hour, but "planck_constant" is rather unwieldy and there is no other widely used abbreviation.

This line of default_en.txt is also used as an example in the documentation on the "Defining units" page, so it should be changed there as well if default_en.txt is changed.

title: Integer Division with Arrays
body:
I am currently using Python 3.3 and Pint 0.4. When integer arrays are used in quantities, division is truncated integer division instead of floating point. For example:

``` python
>>> a = np.array([1]) * ureg['m']

>>> b = np.array([2]) * ureg['s']

>>> a/b
<Quantity([0], 'meter / second')>

>>> a.magnitude / b.magnitude  # Numpy division
array([ 0.5])  # Correct

>>> ureg['1 m'] / ureg['2 s']  # Not using arrays
<Quantity(0.5, 'meter / second')>
```

Is this a bug? I am assuming the intended behavior is to use floating point division where appropriate like Python 3, instead of integer division.

title: get_dimensionality is broken for non multiplicative units
Printing Fractional Exponents Less than 1
body:
Whenever you create a unit with a fractional exponent less than one, it is printed as if the exponent is negative. However, the internal representation of the units is still correct. Consider the following examples:

``` python
>>> ureg['m^0.5']                      # 0.5 < 1
<Quantity(1.0, '1 / meter ** 0.5')>    # The printing indicates m^-0.5
>>> ureg['m^0.5'].units
<UnitsContainer({'meter': 0.5})>       # But the internal representation is fine

>>> ureg['m^-0.5']
<Quantity(1.0, '1 / meter ** 0.5')>    # Notice the same printing as above
>>> ureg['m^-0.5'].units
<UnitsContainer({'meter': -0.5})>

>>> ureg['m^0.5'] * ureg['m^-0.5']
<Quantity(1.0, 'dimensionless')>       # This is still correct

>>> ureg['m^1.1']
<Quantity(1.0, 'meter ** 1.1')>        # 1.1 > 1, correct printing
>>> ureg['m^0.9']
<Quantity(1.0, '1 / meter ** 0.9')>    # 0.9 < 1, printing as if -0.9
```

title: The package is no longer zip_safe due to the implementation of @import
Dimensionless Quantities behave unexpectedly when added to 'raw' numbers
body:
This issue is similar to issue #45 (thanks for fixing that, btw).

When dimensionless Quantities are added to 'raw' number types (int, float, np.float64, etc.), the number seems to be added directly to the magnitude of the Quantity rather than being properly converted to the Quantity's special 'unitless' units. For example:

```
>>> (ureg.km/ureg.m + 1).to('')
<Quantity(2000.0, 'dimensionless')>    # Wrong
>>> (ureg.km/ureg.m).to('') + 1
<Quantity(1001.0, 'dimensionless')>    # Correct
```

title: AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute '_Quantity__handling'
body:
Expected result below ought to be '100 dimensionless'. 

```
self.unitregistry.Quantity(100)
100 dimensionless
self.unitregistry.Quantity('100')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/srv/www/django/development.<hidden>/src/github-texer-pydevsrc/pydevsrc/pydevd_comm.py", line 752, in doIt
    result = pydevd_vars.evaluateExpression(self.thread_id, self.frame_id, self.expression, self.doExec)
  File "/srv/www/django/development.<hidden>/src/github-texer-pydevsrc/pydevsrc/pydevd_vars.py", line 375, in evaluateExpression
    result = eval(compiled, updated_globals, frame.f_locals)
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/srv/www/django/development.<hidden>/src/github-danielsokolowski-django-unitofmeasure/unitofmeasure/danielsokolowski-pint/pint/quantity.py", line 96, in __new__
    inst.__handling = None
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute '_Quantity__handling'
self.unitregistry.Quantity(100.00)
100.0 dimensionless
self.unitregistry.Quantity(Decimal('100'))
100 dimensionless
```

Perhaps consider putting 'beta' status back onto the package, this is not production ready.

title: Dimensionless Quantities behave unexpectedly with some math functions
body:
This behavior applies to both numpy and python standard mathematical functions. Firstly, np.sqrt behaves as expected (provided you work around issue #44 ), while math.sqrt first exhibits the issue:

```
>>> np.sqrt( [1] * ureg.m/ureg.cm )
<Quantity([ 1.], '1 / centimeter ** 0.5 / meter ** 0.5')>
>>> _.to('')
<Quantity([ 10.], 'dimensionless')>
>>> math.sqrt( 1 * ureg.m/ureg.cm )
1.0
```

In the first case, units are retained, so the dimensionless quantity stays correct. However, in the second case I believe the quantity is cast to a float by directly taking the magnitude, which is 1.0 (in units of m/cm) rather than (the truly dimensionless) 100, which is expected.

When casting a dimensionless Quantity to a float, the most sensible float value is the value of the 'true' dimensionless number. Otherwise you get extremely unintuitive results such as

```
>>> float(ureg.V/ureg.mV)
1.0
```

Furthermore, this requires an ugly and cumbersome workaround to work as expected. 

```
>>> float( (ureg.V/ureg.mV).to('') )
1000.0
```

Simply not using python's math module isn't a solution, since similar issues can be found with when using numpy as in `np.sin()`:

```
>>> np.sin( [np.pi/2] * ureg.m/ureg.m )
<Quantity([ 1.], 'dimensionless')>
>>> np.sin( [np.pi/2] * ureg.cm/ureg.m )
<Quantity([ 1.], 'dimensionless')>
>>> np.sin( ([np.pi/2] * ureg.cm/ureg.m).to('') )
<Quantity([ 0.01570732], 'dimensionless')>
```

Interestingly, `np.arccos()` seems to work as expected:

```
>>> np.arccos( [1] * ureg.m/ureg.m )
<Quantity([ 0.], 'radian')>
>>> np.arccos( [1] * ureg.cm/ureg.m )
<Quantity([ 1.56079616], 'radian')>
```

title: Single-number Quantities don't work with ufuncs
body:
Quantity objects that contain a single number (as opposed to an array) are not compatible with numpy ufuncs. For example:

```
>>> np.sqrt( ureg.dimensionless )
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: sqrt
>>> np.sqrt( [1] * ureg.dimensionless )
<Quantity([ 1.], 'dimensionless')>
```

This is in contrast to numpy itself whose ufuncs can apply to a single value:

```
>>> np.sqrt(4)
2.0
```

This makes using unit-ful single-value variables more cumbersome than it should be.

title: Special casing 1 dimension in unit.convert() leads to confusing error
body:
Firstly, pint is really great. I've been looking for a good units package for months - finally stumbled across pint and it's just what I was hoping for. 

Not sure if this is a bug or an enhancement, but the special casing in line 637 of unit.convert() leads to very confusing error messages when performing valid unit conversions where the source units which are defined as a function of multiple units:

```
In [1]: import pint

In [2]: pint.__version__
Out[2]: '0.2'

In [3]: ureg = pint.UnitRegistry()

In [4]: ureg.define('molar = mole / liter = M')

In [5]: t = 4 * ureg['mM']

In [6]: t
Out[6]: <Quantity(4, 'millimolar')>

In [7]: t.to('mole / liter')

DimensionalityError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-5efb6e276de9> in <module>()
----> 1 t.to('mole / liter')

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pint/quantity.pyc in to(self, other)
    189         """
    190         ret = copy.copy(self)
--> 191         ret.ito(other)
    192         return ret
    193 

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pint/quantity.pyc in ito(self, other)
    178             other = UnitsContainer(other)
    179 
--> 180         self._magnitude = self._REGISTRY.convert(self._magnitude, self._units, other)
    181         self._units = other
    182         return self

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pint/unit.py in convert(self, value, src, dst)
    639                 raise DimensionalityError(src, dst,
    640                                           self.get_dimensionality(src),
--> 641                                           self.get_dimensionality(dst))
    642             src_unit, src_value = list(src.items())[0]
    643             src_unit = self._units[src_unit]

DimensionalityError: Cannot convert from 'millimolar' ([substance] / [length] ** 3) to 
'mole / liter'  ([substance] / [length] ** 3)
```

I'd naively expect that to work correctly. The workaround is to convert to molar rather than mol/L.

title: Unicode support
body:

```
percent = [fraction]; offset: 0 = %
permille = percent / 10 = ‰
```

When I parse percents like 100 %, this works as expected. However with 100 ‰, I get the following error:

```
  File "/var/atmiz/eggs/Pint-0.2-py2.7.egg/pint/quantity.py", line 88, in __new__
```

title: Watt-hour is defined incorrectly
body: In default_en.txt, watt-hour is defined as watt / hour.  It should be watt \* hour.

title: Temperature conversions are incorrect
body:
``` python
>>> from pint import UnitRegistry
>>> ureg = UnitRegistry()
>>> Q_ = ureg.Quantity
>>> Q_('0 * degK').to('degC')
<Quantity(0.0, 'degC')>
>>> Q_('0 * degC').to('degF')
<Quantity(0.0, 'degF')>
>>> Q_('100 * degC').to('degF')
<Quantity(55.55555555555556, 'degF')>
>>> Q_('212 * degF').to('degC')
<Quantity(381.6, 'degC')>
```

It seems like the "offset" parameter in the definition file is being ignored.  The test_offset method in test_pint.py is decorated with unittest.expectedFailure.
